Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multilevel Physics in the Study of Solids: Modeling, Analysis and Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The performance of nanometer-sized devices can be greatly affected by the formation and propagation of defects, such as cracks. Given that this process involves breaking the chemical bonds in the solid lattice, a quantum-mechanical description is necessary. However, a fully atomistic description of the problem is not viable. The PI proposes to develop analysis-based numerical methodologies that couple an atomistic description near the location of the defect with a coarse-grained description far from it. Quantum-mechanical effects are studied in the context of Density-Functional Theory. This approach can effectively remove the limitation in the size of the system considered, and could gear the development of nanometer-sized devices in new directions.

This proposal also includes the development of special courses in multiscale modeling, and an undergraduate research component in a vertical environment that involves undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows. In addition, the proposal includes outreach to local high schools. By exposing students to mathematics at such an early stage, the investigator hopes to awaken in them the desire to pursue a career in mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Most physical systems present important features at multiple spatial or temporal scales, and can be modeled at different levels of detail: Quantum mechanics describes the behavior of an electronic system at the microscopic level. The motion of atoms can be described by molecular dynamics with empirical potentials.  At a macroscopic level, a system can be described using continuum mechanics, e.g., the Navier-Stokes equations that describe how fluids evolve, and Continuum Elasticity, which describes how solids deform. The main objectives of multiscale modeling are to analytically connect the different levels of description, to perform systematic coarse-graining, and to develop efficient numerical methodologies.

An example of such a system is the study of fracture in a solid, which is of importance in the design of new metallic alloys, for example. Fracture involves atomic bond-breaking, and therefore an accurate description can be obtained only through quantum mechanics. A full solution of the quantum mechanical system is too costly and impractical. Since far from the fracture the solid can be accurately described at a continuum level, it seems desirable to combine both approaches. How to match both descriptions seamlessly is a very challenging problem at the core of multiscale analysis. In this project the PI has developed a methodology for the study of defects in crystalline solids within the context of quantum mechanics, in which an atomistic description is used near the fracture, and far from it, a coarse-grained model derived by upscaling the quantum mechanical description is used.

Similarly, soft materials are complicated mixtures characterized by many components, multiple coexisting phases, and structural heterogeneities spanning a broad range of length scales.  Examples include polymeric fluids, liquid crystals, copolymers, emulsions, and blends, which have become a part of everyday life. These materials are processed in the liquid phase and their nano- and micro- scale structures subjected to processing flows determine the macroscopic behavior and properties such as toughness, ductility, optical clarity, or thermal conductivity.

The design of new soft material formulations typically proceeds by trial and error experimentation. This is an expensive and time-consuming process and thus there is a clear scientific and technological need for a predictive theory along with computational tools for this class of problems. An approach based only on a physical model with atomic resolution is impossible to use for dense materials that exhibit spatial heterogeneities on scales much larger than atomic dimensions, as is typically the case in practical polymeric formulations. Some intermediate multiscale approach is necessary.

In the emerging area of nanotechnology many practical applications of polymers and other soft condensed matter systems involve mixtures that through equilibrium self-assembly or nonequilibrium processing steps develop complex, multiphase morphologies. The desirable properties of such materials depend critically on the ability to control and manipulate morphology by adjusting a combination of molecular and macroscopic variables. In a highly interdisciplinary effort carried out with researchers in the mathematics, chemical engineering, and materials science departments, the PI has developed effective models and numerical methodologies for the study of polymers and liquid crystals.

Broader Impacts: The project has had significant impact in the development of methodologies for the simulation of solvent evaporation, ubiquitous in polymer processing, and of high interest in understanding morphology selection mechanism in low-cost organic solar cells, which are important as a renewable energy source, and for sustainable environment and national energy security...
